Horizon Riders allows players to control any of the four squad members on their mission to defeat Thau-Phi, dashing at high-speed through the surface of planet Zethos on powerful hoverboards while destroying the renegade cybernetic army with their futuristic arsenal. Each character carries two weapons, each with different rates of fire, damage and bullet spread and these weapons can be upgraded through use.

The hoverboard can be controlled with a Wii Balance Board, allowing players to turn left and right to avoid enemy fire using their own bodies. The game also supports the use of the Wii Zapper for aiming and firing.

A demo version of the Horizon Riders is available today and for four weeks. This demo version features three levels and one of the four Riders that are available in the full version.

Horizon Riders is the first WiiWare game both created and published by Sabarasa.

Source: The Publisher Website.

118432.name: Art of Ink
118432.description:
Pick a character, grip your stylus and ink your way to become the top tattoo artists in Art of Ink, the new Nintendo DSiWare™ game from Sabarasa. Meet a crew of quirky characters, get to know their hopes and intimate secrets and select a tattoo that fits their personal history. Tattoos are very personal and each one should be unique!

Your Stylus turns into a powerful tattoo machine and you should use it with precision and responsibility. Keep your lines clean and your client comfortable or you are not getting tipped!

With three playable characters to choose from, follow their meteoric rise from newbie apprentices to Tattoo Masters as they face challenges from demanding celebrities and other prominent tattoo artists!

Welcome to the colourful world of tattoo culture!

Source: The Publisher Website.

118433.name: Primrose
118433.description:
Take your time, set your own pace, establish your own goals and adapt your play style to whatever you feel is more fun.

Primrose rules are easy: There are no time limits, no levels or arbitrary objectives and no constraints. You must place pairs of tiles on a game grid and attempt to corral groups of tiles with pieces of a different colour. When that happens, surrounded tiles disappear and surrounding tiles change colours, allowing chain effects to trigger combos for massive points. You can play for long matches, surviving against the increasing difficulty, or just go all out on a huge single move combo for millions of points.

Relax, enjoy and welcome to Primrose.

Source: The Publisher Website.

Primrose is a Jason Rohrer game.

118434.name: Kung Fu Panda: Legendary Warriors
118434.description:
Revisit the amazing and heroic world of Kung Fu Panda, reuniting with old friends and meeting new enemies in this humorous, brawling game. Use the intuitive Wii controls to feel the action and perform a multitude of Kung Fu combos, in unique worlds inspired from the movie !

Source: The Developer Website.

118435.name: Save the Turtles
118435.description:
Save the Turtles is a puzzle game for Nintendo DSiWare™ where players must help baby sea turtles to hatch and then aid them in their struggle to get to the water, avoiding obstacles (such as predators and debris) and racing against the unforgiving tropical sun.

The game takes players over 32 of the world’s most exotic beaches in a quest to help tiny turtles find their new home on the sea. Players must use the stylus to rub the Touch Screen on the Nintendo DSi™ and dig eggs from the sand, then help the little reptiles crack out of them by tapping over the eggs.

Once the turtles are born, they need to be lined up in thee or more while avoiding crabs, seagulls and litter, so that a sea wave can be summoned and take them safely to sea. The game features four game modes, including both a main campaign and “Turtles Forever” mode with endless replay value.

Source: The Publisher Website.

118436.name: Kyotokei
118436.description:
The powerful witch Rika has invaded the peaceful realm of Estaria with an army of monsters!

The magic brothers Kyo and Kei are the only ones who can stop her! Use your powerful aura of protection to absorb the enemy spells and unleash their power all at once! Travel through dark swamps, cold mountains, dangerous caves full of lava, and much more!

The powerful protection aura that surrounds you will be of great help, absorbing all the shots of the same color as the aura. You can change the color of your protection aura and the color of your shots by pressing a button, but beware: if you are touched by an enemy shot of the wrong color, you are dead! Face Rika and free Estaria from her menace!

Source: The Developer Website.

118437.name: Legend of the Dragon
118437.description:
Translated from French

History:

The history of Legend of the Dragon begins in China. In a world where old meets new, where the shadow coexists with the light, the universal balance between yin and yang is maintained by the custodian of the temple, the golden dragon. When it is time to choose the new keeper, a brother is chosen. Jealous of her brother who was chosen in her place, a Chinese girl turns to the forces of evil to destroy the 12 lost temples of the Chinese zodiac and to defeat her brother. A legend says that some soldiers can earn the powers of several guardians and thus potentially become invincible ...


Features:

- 18 playable characters
- The player can move easily on a map and visit the various guardians
- All areas of combat in the series is animated in the game: The 12 sacred temples, The Dragon Dojo, The Zodiac Master's hideout, The Temple of Shadow Dragon, The Great Wall of China, Hong Kong Bay!
-8 Game modes: Play Quest mode, Arcade mode, Training mode, Survival mode, Time Attack mode, versus mode, Team Battle mode, Tag mode
- 3D animation.

Source: The Developer Website.

118438.name: Trolls on Treasure Island
118438.description:
From the manual

When Samantha and Norbert were baby Trolls their Grampa told them tales of lost treasures stashed on a mysterious far away island. That was long ago.

Yesterday, while wind surfing, our teenage troll twins came upon an undiscovered and uncharted island filled with excitement, adventure and hidden treasure. Exploring the island they soon
realized it was the same island their Grampa told them about when they were very young.

The twins passed through vine covered trees filled with multi-colored birds of every description. They were overwhelmed with the beauty of the island but they couldn't help thinking about the warning Grampa always told them: "If you ever come upon this magical island like I did when I was young - explore it with great care. There are many strange and dangerous creatures that make the island their home. Venomous snakes, giant flying insects, and huge slobbering jaws to name just a few. Remember, always be careful!"

118439.name: Hero Academy
videogamehonor: 2013 D.I.C.E. Cellular/Mobile Game of the Year Winner
2013 Game Developers Choice Awards Best Handheld/Mobile Game of the Year Nominee
118439.description:
Test your skills in this light-hearted battle between friends! Diverse teams have gathered to engage in friendly contests on the Academy playfields. Will your team emerge triumphant? The Academy extends a warm greeting to all players – whether they’re already heroes, or simply heroes in training!

Multiplayer tactics gaming on the go – challenge friends to one-on-one battles via online multiplayer

Asynchronous strategy – play a heated bout in twenty minutes or across a full day, whenever you have a few moments

Quick to Learn – Casual players can attack without mercy, while tactics game buffs will love the strategic cat-and-mouse gameplay

Heroic visuals – Colorful fantasy graphics highlight each character and the board’s boost tiles

Vicious variety – each team has five unique units with different strengths and magical abilities

Source: The Publisher Website.

118440.name: Flick Kick Football
videogamehonor: 2011 IGF Awards Best Mobile Game of the Year Nominee
118440.description:
Set in the Golden Age of Football. Experience the beautiful game the way it used to be played with Flick Kick Football for iOS and Android.

Curve, lob, drive and shoot the ball from all over the pitch using Flick Kick’s trademark precise real-time ball control!

Kick It Old School!

Multiple Modes including:

Online Multiplayer and Classic pass & play!

Practice Mode, to get your game up to par (Now updated!)

Bullseye Mode, can you smash the targets?

Arcade Mode, to show what you can do when it really counts

Time Attack for those that like to race the clock, or with limited time for greatness

Skillshot Mode – a true test for the Flick Kick Football pros – how many times can you shoot the ball into the Skill Zones in a minute!

With..

Intuitive Flick Kicking – Sweep your finger across the ball to drive, curve and power the ball past walls of defenders

Unique ‘Golden Era’ of Football Presentation – Immerse yourself in graphics that will bring the nostalgia of the era back

OpenFeint Leaderboards and Achievements – So the world can see that you’re a better player than your friends

Super Sharp graphics for Retina & iPad screens

Source: The Publisher Website.

118441.name: Portal (1986)
118441.description:
Portal is a mix between a computer novel and an interactive game. It was published for the Amiga in 1986 by Activision, written by Rob Swigart, produced by Brad Fregger and programmed by Nexa Corporation. Versions for the Macintosh, Commodore 64, Apple II, and the IBM PC were later released. A unique game for its time, Portal was one part text-driven adventure (à la Zork or Planetfall) but with a graphical interface.

Source: Wikipedia, "Portal (interactive novel)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

118442.name: The Game of London
118442.description:
A Victorian card game, featuring 55 cards showing the contemporary locations in London. Many of these buildings are no longer around and, if you know London at all, you will notice the fact that still-existing buildings are not hemmed in by modern developments and office blocks as they are now.

The game is played with 64 cards - 55 picture cards, 8 District cards and 1 Key Card. The Key Card contains the numbers of picture cards in each district. It is placed face-up in the middle of the table. The remaining 63 cards are all shuffled and dealt to the players in rotation until the pack is exhausted.

The game is commenced by the player to the left of the dealer asking any other player for a card to complete a district of which he holds at least one card in his hand. If a player asked has such a card in his hand, he is bound to surrender it, and the first player then asks for another and so on until refused, when the right of asking is transferred to the player who refused him. The latter, in like manner, then asks for a card to complete a district in his hand, and so the game proceeds until all the districts are completed. Each district, when completed, is to be laid on the table (face downwards) by the player, and the game is won by that player who, at the conclusion, holds the most districts. A player may, at any time, refer to the Key Card in the centre of the table.

The game is undated, but one of the picture cards refers to "the late Sir Gilbert Scott", the most famous Victorian architect. He died in 1878 so the game was probably new around 1880.

118443.name: Jugger: An Indian Game
118443.description:
Early 20th century card game published by a Missionary Society, with the intention of making people aware of their work in the sub-continent. The game is fundamentally about India although Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) is included.

Three games are mentioned in the rules; Jugger, Picture Lotto and Buss. The former is the main game, the Lotto game has nothing to do with the traditional Lotto game, and there are no rules (in my set) to the game of Buss..

Players ask each other for cards in a set they already have at least one card in that set in their hand. In Jugger, the object is to collect the most sets. In Lotto, the object is to claim the most cards by answering correctly when a question is read out.

General Notes from the rules;
Picture Cards
At the top of each picture card there is the name of a place where missionaries are working. In the game these places are called 'Juggers', the phonetic spelling of 'Jugah', a Hindustani word meaning 'place' or 'post'. Where a place is not well known and the pronunciation is difficult, phonetic spelling is given.

Map Cards
These are the Key Cards. Each map gives the names of the Juggers (marked by a heavy dot) in the set.

Question Cards
All the question cards are essential for Picture Lotto.

118444.name: Wineology
118444.description:
Wineology: The Extraordinary Wine Tasting Game" is a marketing/promotional board game released by E & J Gallo Winery, to promote their line of "Turning Leaf" wines. It is a wine-themed derivative of Trivial Pursuit and is similar to Trivial Pursuit in some respects.

The game involves tasting five varietals of "Turning Leaf" wines (Sauvignon Blanc, Chardonnay, Merlot, Zinfandel, and Cabernet Sauvignon) and answering specific questions about them. The players (or team of players) taste one wine at a time, in a specific order, and must correctly answer questions in four categories (Wine Senses, Food & Wine, Wine Making, & Wild Card) in order to move on to the next varietal.

The first player (or team of players) to answer all four questions correctly in each of the five varietals is declared the winner.

118445.name: Le Petit Poucet et la maison de l'ogre
118445.description:
"Tom Thumb and the Ogre's house"
In this game of cooperation Tom Thumb and his brothers move around the game board and must find all the stones before nightfall. Some stones are trapped (wolves are hidden nearby) and require support from the players to break free. It is possible to make the game harder by increasing the number of wolves hidden.

118446.name: Gildenbrief (Issue 27- Mar 1993)
rpgpublisher: Verlag für Fantasy- und Science Fiction-Spiele
118446.description: This issue contains an article about the war god Laran and its cult. It also contains new magical artifacts (mostly weapons).

118448.description:
The ogre fell asleep at the foot of a tree, Tom Thumb and his brothers will benefit for they rob him of all his gold?

In turn, the player must roll a die and advance the number of spaces indicated, and then act on the square where he stopped taking gold at the ogre, take his next turn etc.
But beware, fall on the bell box too often wakes the ogre!

Players win if they get back together all the pieces of the ogre before he wakes up.
118448.name: Petit Poucet

118449.description:
"Eat the Soup" in English
Players move around the board and try to eat the entire bowl of soup! Otherwise the witch will eat the players! The game can be played both in cooperative or competitive mode.

The game is won if the players have finished their soup before the fourth child is stolen by the witch.
118449.name: Mange ta soupe!

118450.name: Le Petit Poucet
118450.description:
Players have six tiles in hand. They choose one to create a path that leads to the center, the blue flower.

There are many obstacles on the tiles. Sometimes a player is completely blocked, and has no other choice but to give up.

Player who reach first to the tile with blue flower is the winner.

118451.name: Addigolo
118451.description:
Players collect cards of the same color pairs when their sum is equal to 10, 20 or 30.
The goal is to get the most out of the red cards.
The part may take place in one or more rounds.
A round ends when players have more cards.

118452.description: Die Tore der Welt: Das Kartenspiel, a card game version of World Without End, takes the basic mechanism of the big game and breaks it down to a game with 90 cards. Each turn an event card is flipped that defines available player actions. Players collect stone, cloth, piety and medical knowledge to score victory points. The game is played over two chapters, and each chapter is played in 12 rounds. At the end of each chapter, players have to meet certain requirements which are not exactly known beforehand to avoid negative points. The player with the most victory points wins.
118452.name: Die Tore der Welt: Das Kartenspiel
boardgamepodcastepisode: Die Tore der Welt - Das Kartenspiel (Kosmos): Spiele-Podcast Nr. 144

118453.name: Gildenbrief (Issue 28- Aug 1993)
rpgpublisher: Verlag für Fantasy- und Science Fiction-Spiele
118453.description: This issue contains a circus as setting with adventure ideas and articles of the seagod Nothun and its cult.

118454.name: Gildenbrief (Issue 29- Oct 1993)
rpgpublisher: Verlag für Fantasy- und Science Fiction-Spiele
118454.description: This issue contains the adventure "Die Zeichen im Wald"

118455.name: Gildenbrief (Issue 30 - May 1994)
rpgpublisher: Verlag für Fantasy- und Science Fiction-Spiele
118455.description: This issue contains the adventure "Trommel und Pferd", also articles of the plants and herbs in Waeland. Another series of articles about the falconry.

118456.name: Jungle Jinks
118456.description:
"Consisting of forty eight pictorial cards illustrative of the Adventures and Games of the Boys of Dr. Lion's Jungle School from Constance Stannard Chapman's Original Designs."

Each numbered cards of the sets are similar, for example number 2 of each set shows an animal with a musical instrument. There are 48 cards arranged in 3 sets of 16, each lettered A, B or C and numbered 1 to 16; all the illustrations are different and have an appropriate title.

A set number of cards are dealt, probably 5, to each player. The object of the game is to complete a set of three cards, one from each letter, for example a set would be cards A1, B1 and C1, not 1 to 16 of A. The player to the dealer's left begins the play by asking his next neighbor on his left side for A, B or C of any set to complete the three cards of the set. When a player has succeeded in completing a set, he must show the completed set, and may then draw a card from the pool but no card must be drawn from the pool except upon the completion of a set, and only one card drawn.

The winner of the game is the one who completes the most sets.

This game is copyright Thomas De La Rue on the box, but the rules say that H P Gibson are the copyright holders. As far as I know, there has never been a reissue of the game so I assume H P Gibson still hold the copyright. However, I am crediting them both with this game. Almost certainly, De La Rue printed it and H P Gibson distributed it.

118457.name: Battle Royale: The First Silesian War
118457.description:
(From the game's Consimworld folder)

Battle Royale is the first in a series of games dealing with campaigns of famous 18th century military leaders (Frederick the Great and Marlborough among others).

Battle Royale is a simple wargame about the First Silesian War, 1741-42. The campaign marks the debut of Frederick the Great's military career, however inauspicious this was for him personally. The war began with Prussia taking advantage of a perceived weakness of the new and first Queen of Austria, Maria Theresa, when she assumed the throne. Bavaria, France, and Saxony contested Maria's claim to the Austrian crown, as well as having long disputes over their borders or policies of the Austrian empire. Prussia sought to claim the rich province of Silesia from Austria and in a whirlwind (for the time) campaign in 1740 seized virtually the entire province. Prussia's Allies took longer to mobilize their forces and work out the disputes they had with one another to form a coalition to defeat Austria and overthrow its new queen. A long era of war in central Europe was about to begin. Can you do as well, or better, than your historical counterparts?

The game uses the "chit-pull" system with a deck of cards similar to Paul Rohrbaugh's Pocket Battle Games series from Against the Odds.

118458.name: Rings of Jerusalem
118458.description:
From 1KM1KT description:

We are the Sabbath Ghosts. Devout Jews preform no work from sundown Friday until Saturday night. No switches are flipped, no coin changes hands, no creature harmed. But our enemies do not rest on holy days.

Thus the Rabbis of of our colony have made dispensation. Each member of our group is officially dead and symbolically buried. Upon rising from the shallow crypts, we are spirits, exempt from the laws that bind men. Neither the grace of the sabbath bride nor the nor the commandment “Thou shall not murder” prevents us from doing whatever is necessary to safeguard the children of Israel.

Shema Yisrael! If you come to Saturn, spirits protect you.

118460.name: Sputnik Lost
118460.description:
From 1KM1KT description:
Russia ushered in the space age on October 4, 1957 with the launch Sputnik. That original 58cm metal sphere would in turn lead to a race between the superpowers to put men on the moon. After America won, all references to the Soviet moon program were denied, until the glasnost period of the early 199s.

Sputnik Lost is a reconstruction of an attempt to put men on the moon, less than two weeks before the launch of Apollo 11.

118461.name: Bible Bingo
118461.description:
A religious take on the Bingo type of game. The game for the youngest in the family is straight Bingo, although adults should make sure the children understand the scripture references on their bingo card.

The game for older children requires them to name a verse or story from the bible relating to the colour they draw. If other players have that colour and can name another verse or story reference, they too can cover the square on their bingo card.

In all versions, the first to create a line of five covered squares, wins.

118463.name: Hookipa
118463.description:
Original board game
The aim is to complete the Olympic Triangle Course by rounding all the bouys in the correct, predetermined sequence.

Surf Slalom
The aim is to be the first player to complete the course of 6 bouys. This must be done in the right way and in the right order and ending up back at the start.

Each player has a miniature sailboard and a points card. Dice are thrown to determine the boardspeed (1 or 2 boardspeed drops 1, 3 or 4 boardspeed remains the same, 5 or 6 boardspeed increases 1). Cards are used to help or hinder progress.

118464.name: Groove
118464.description:
You must be the first to bring your four pawns of their starting line to their finish line: The only slight problem is that the finish line is located on the side of your opponent. So we have to use tricks to get there.
You have several techniques: one to protect your camp, another, called GROOVE to move your pieces strategically. But in both cases it will sacrifice one of your pieces!

118465.name: Quiz Master
118465.description:
A quiz game for two or more players. Sliding cards have picture clues on one side and questions and answers on the reverse.

Choose a level, easy, medium or hard and push out a card to reveal the picture. Answer three related questions and score the points.

Play against one other person or in teams.

118466.name: Lapipoker
118466.description:
the object of the gmae is to earn money wagered at the parties To do this You must have a combination of higher than your opponent to win the this..

LAPIPOKER cards represent two cards at once which are situated in two lines: one red and one black.
Cards are on the table next to each other respecting the colored lines and each player will build the best poker on its own line of color - it should be noted that the cards are of the game for two players simultaneously. So, each player makes his own game but also try to ruin the game for his opponent playing the card on the table.

118467.name: Stoïck
118467.description: The goal is to create a family of four cards of the same color clover. To do this, you can share hands, draw a cards, share your game with someone, complete your family with one or more jokers, bring down the joker of an opponent and especially announce "Stoick" when you made ​​your family.

118468.name: Bibliophile
118468.description:
The game of literary knowledge and skill

Object of the Game
To win the most cards.

Bibliophile Cards
Each card consists of the opening and closing lines of a well known piece of literature as well as its title, author and publication date.

To Win a Card
Players or teams of players must identify from the opening and closing lines, any one of the following: Title, Author or Decade of publication.

118469.name: The Moron Test: Section 1
118469.description:
User Summary

The Moron Test: Section 1 is a seemingly simple game but one you will probably fail a lot! It´s a hilarious puzzle game.

118470.name: Faith of Sigmar
rpgpodcastepisode: Die Söhne Sigmars bringen den Frühling
118470.description:
From the Publishers Website:

Priests of Sigmar, rejoice! Your prayers have been answered. The Empire’s patron deity has not forgotten his people in their time of greatest need. While Beastmen and bands of Chaos marauders threaten the Empire’s borders, cultists summon daemons, foment rebellion, and sow corruption within its cities. Against these threats, devout Sigmarites take arms, lifting their warhammers and preparing for battle, and Sigmar grants them new powers to smite their foes.

Fantasy Flight Games is proud to announce that Faith of Sigmar, a Print on Demand supplement for Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay, is now available through our webstore to bolster your campaign and the Empire.

Faith of Sigmar introduces fifteen new blessings and two new items full of righteous wrath!

Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay: Faith of Sigmar - Print on Demand

“Sigmar is the hammer, and I am his holy anvil. Woe to any caught between us!”
–Juergen Dunkel, zealot
Smite your foes with the Faith of Sigmar! This Print on Demand expansion for Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay introduces fifteen blessings and two powerful items. Above all, the life of a priest of Sigmar is a life of war–an endless war waged against the Empire’s many foes, and Faith of Sigmar grants your priests new strength and options as they follow in Sigmar’s footsteps.
Faith of Sigmar is a 20-card POD pack, consisting of:
•Fifteen blessings spanning Rank 1 to Rank 5
•Two item cards
•Three rules cards

118471.name: The Moron Test: Section 2
118471.description:
User Summary

The Moron Test: Section 2 is a seemingly simple game but one you will probably fail a lot! It´s a hilarious puzzle game and the continuation in The Moron Test series.

118472.name: Windgeflüster (Issue 27 - Oct 1994)
118472.description: This issue contains an article about the clothing of characters. And a Cyperpunk Universal adventure "2 Jokers in 1 game"

118473.name: Fantasy Holidays, Volume 1
118473.description:
From Introduction:

Since the beginning of time the various civilizations of the known world have celebrated particular events through the observation of holidays. While holidays are loosely mentioned in the standard gaming system there is little amount of continuing information to better describe such significant markings of time.

In this electronic role playing product you’ll find a variety of holidays that are suitable for the different seasons of the year. While this information contains no new game rules the use of such holidays in an adventure helps set the pace for the visual surroundings that the exploring characters may see and/or experience.

118474.name: Fantasy Home Plans: Cozy Cottage
118474.description:
From Introduction:

The home featured in this edition of Fantasy Home Plans is a lovely little one room cottage that is quaint and simple yet sturdy in construction. The cottage features stone exterior walls, a wood singled roof, secure stone floor, and a fine quality chimney and fireplace. Simple shuttered window openings add a bit of light into the cottage and the optional furniture listings provide enough furnishings to keep a single resident or a couple happy. Though a bit more pricey than some villager homes, this quaint little cottage is well built and sure to provide a lifetime of simple comfort.

118475.name: Fantasy Home Plans: Explorer's Haven
118475.description:
From Introduction:

After a long, hard walk on the road to fame and glory many adventurers seek out a cozy little home of their very own to which they can return and kick back their tired feet and worried brow. Such a place should be quaint enough to allow the adventurer to hide away for a bit yet built well enough to allow a bit of dry warmth even in the worst of weather.

The home that is presented in this edition of Fantasy Home Plans is perfect for such a dwelling. Having four rooms spread over a total of 500 square feet the home is large enough to allow the owner to entertain a few guests from time to time yet small enough to keep that charming appeal of a having a little village cottage.

118476.name: Fantasy Home Plans: Peasant's Home
118476.description:
From Introduction:

Thatch roof, dirt floor, and simple walls of rough plank and mud plaster, that’s the home of a commoner. This detailed, one room dwelling is perfect for detailing the homes of the local peasantry.

118477.name: Fantasy Street Life: Profit Street
118477.description:
From Introduction:

More of a general name than a singular, given location, Profit Street is any crowded urban street where all walks of life gather for daily business. From beggars and harlots pandering about to the wealthiest of aristocrats and officials, all varieties of folk can be found drifting about on this busy, city road. It is on such a street that one might be hassled by beggars and harlots hustling for petty coin, pelted with rocks by naughty children, engage in business with merchants local or foreign, and welcomed with warm wishes by drunkards, cult followers, and the most upstanding of citizens alike.

118478.name: Windgeflüster (Issue 28 - Dec 1994)
rpgissuearticle: Ein kleiner Sprung durch die Zeit
Feature: Der Wahnsinn mit den Sammelkarten
It came from the late, late, late show
Tod der Wanderer zwischen den Welten
Willkommen in der Höhle des Trolls
rpg: In Nomine Satanis / Magna Veritas (1st Edition)
118478.description: This issue contains an universal adventure "Eine Phiole Gift"

118479.name: The Tome Of Arcane Mycology
118479.description:
From Introduction:

Back in 2005 Top Fashion Games went out on a left field limb and released a very different sort of product entitled Fantasy Fungi. As this product was rather unique in subject and content the speculation was that the game market audience would either love it, kinda like it, or flat out hate it. At Top Fashion Games we were dreaming of the “loving it”, figuring on (with fingers crossed) the “kinda liking it”, and fearing the “flat out hating it”. Much to our surprise the results of the pdf release gave our humble company quite a few 5 star ratings and Fantasy Fungi has become one of our most profitable sellers.

Though future releases of Fantasy Fungi were speculated we never intended for the first release to be a “core book” of any sort and as such there has been a bit of difficulty of reintroducing the nature of our game system fungi in other products without having to repeat a bit of lengthy terminologies and explanations. As such, it was decided that we should release a new fungus book that would serve as a core rules system. Such a product should carry the appropriate information regarding the make up of the logical rules surrounding the fungi and should also carry any initial needed extras, such as important or extremely useful feats, monsters, and so forth. Finally, in order to make such core rules regarding fungi extremely accessible the pdf book should be offered for free over the net.

The pdf that you are now looking at is the results of this decision. By taking a wee bit from the first Fantasy Fungi book and adding in a great deal of new, fresh material we have created the “core fungus” book of our desired intentions.

118480.name: Fungal Festerings: Heroic Legends
118480.description:
From Introduction:

Usually when a party of adventurers come across a patch of fungi they tend to avoid. Fungi, for the most part, is said to be either poisonous, the culprit of some nasty, lingering infection, or cause someone to nearly suffocate with a sudden cloud of air fouling spores. There are some fungal growths, however, with properties so beneficial that they are considered to be the stuff of legend. This edition of Fungal Festerings examines six different fungi that are well worthy of an adventurer’s interest.

This product is an expansion of The Tome Of Arcane Mycology.

118481.name: Windgeflüster (Issue 29 - Apr 1995)
118481.description: This issue contains an article about magic in roleplay games. And an adventure "Ein ganz einfacher Auftrag"

118482.name: Fungal Festerings: Cavern Habitat
118482.description:
From Introduction:

While deep, dark underground areas usually provide shelter, a stable temperature, and quite often a source of water they often tend to lack in other things that living creatures need to thrive. A light source would be nice, a continual offering of edible food would be great, and fresh, clean air to breathe is most desperately needed. But, beyond magic, how can one acquire such things underground? The answer is fungi.

This edition of Fungal Festerings provides six different fungal growths that make caves and caverns a bit more habitable.

This product is an expansion of The Tome Of Arcane Mycology.

118483.name: Windgeflüster (Issue 34 - Oct 1996)
rpgissuearticle: Popcorn, Blut und Gelächter (Seite des Blutes- Special)
Regionalvertretungen der GFR e.V. RV Münsterland
Unglaubliche Wahrheiten aus der Welt des Rollenspiels
Wie schreibe ich ein gutes Abenteuer
118483.description: This issue contains an artice how to write a good adventure. It alos conatins a part of the Myras setting.

118484.name: Land Plots: Oak Meadows
118484.description:
From Introduction:

While gold and silver is nice there are other rewards of more useful value. Land, for example, is quite a tempting reward for the party of adventurers who are finding their selves in need of a fortification if not just a place to park their excess gear. This first installment of Land Plots focuses on a nice tract of land located in a small, rural area simply known as Oak Meadows.

Covering a total of 90 acres, the land plot offers the adventuring party a combination of farm ready meadows, rolling hills, and timber rich woodlands. There is also a limestone cave
and a creek of pure, clear water that the characters might find to be useful. Whether available for purchase or intended to be used as a means of rewarding the characters for saving the day (and perhaps the village) the land plot is worth 5600 gold coins.

118485.name: Lesser Fantasy Treasures Volume 1
118485.description:
From Introduction:

Coins are fairly lightweight for their value, easy to spend, but terribly, terribly boring at times. While those novice adventurers may be more concerned about filling their coffers for better gear the constant pandering of coppers, silver, and gold can get a bit drab at times. Lesser Items of Wealth offers twenty different treasures that offer an alternative solution to the otherwise boring bag of coins. With values ranging from 1 gold coin to 100 gold coins, these items are mainly intended to add a bit of flavor to treasure holdings of lower level adventures.

118486.name: Lesser Threats: Snakes
118486.description:
User summary:

A collection of mundane snakes for use with OGL material.

118487.name: Marvelous Mundane Items
118487.description:
From Introduction:

Alchemists need substances, blacksmiths need ore, minters need precious metals, jewelers need gems, and furnace ovens need coal. And adventurers, of course, need a wide variety of mines to explore and exploit. This one page reference sheet provides you with the basics of setting up a random mine. You supply the dice.

118488.name: Moneychanger's Companion Volume 1
118488.description:
From Introduction:

While having three or four different types of coins in a fantasy role playing game may seem suitable enough as far as figuring up the costs of this and that such a slim variety seems rather bland. With all the different cultures and intelligent races that inhabit the fantasy realm why should such individuals merely settle for a simple, universal system of currency. In this edition of the moneychanger’s companion we will look at a wide variety of coinage that can be easily added to your fantasy campaign realm.

118489.name: Moneychanger's Companion Volume 2
118489.description:
From Introduction:

While having three or four different types of coins in a fantasy role playing game may seem suitable enough as far as figuring up the costs of this and that such a slim variety seems rather bland. With all the different cultures and intelligent races that inhabit the fantasy realm why should such individuals merely settle for a simple, universal system of currency.

In this edition of the moneychanger’s companion we will look at a wide variety of coinage that can be easily added to your fantasy campaign realm.

118490.name: The History Channel presents Time Troopers
118490.description:
Answer history trivia questions correctly and advance along a board track. Answer wrong and go back. Fate cards may force you go back as well. Play cooperatively or competitively with up to 4 players.

Hosted by John Cleese as Agent Wormold, there are video clips that have to be identified as well as questions.

118491.name: The Marmot
118491.description:
The Marmot is a limited edition playbook for Apocalypse World.

From the introduction:
"One thing that hasn’t changed since the apocalypse: people do bad things to each other and expect to get away with it. If there’s any marmot who can untangle the secrets, the lies, and the pain to find some justice in this filthy, filthy world, it’s you."

118492.name: Octopath
118492.description:
Octopath is a tile laying, road building and discovery game for two or more players. Players control crews of dwarves operating in an unexplored part of the country. The dwarves build roadways on the valley floors, and mine the mountains, following rumours of great wealth to be found: emeralds, sapphires, rubies and gold. But not all mountains have a source of wealth. Some have mines which initially look promising, but result in dead ends. Others are not suitable for mining at all, and the dwarves just build passes into the next valley.

You try to earn bags of gold by getting your crews to build looping roads that the farmers in the valleys use, and roads that run from one mine to another. But beware, other dwarven crews are also building roads and excavating in the mountains, and they can join their road up with one of your roads to capitalize on your finds, or make one of your roads join two dead ends, losing you money!

There are two types of tiles used in Octopath. Larger octagonal tiles are the valley floors, and are just used to construct roads. Each valley tile has four road sections each with entry/exit points on two of the 8 sides of the octagon. There are 72 tiles consisting of 4 copies of each of 18 different tiles. When placed edge to edge, the road segments join into meandering roads.

Octagonal tiles do not tessellate – when you place four octagonal tiles touching each other, there is a small square space between them. The square spaces represent the mountains, and when the mountains are explored, small mountain tiles are placed in the square spaces. Each mountain tile has four road entry/exit points, one on each side. These may join together to form passes through the mountains, or may lead to a terminus, which is either a mine of a specific type (red = ruby, green = emerald, blue = sapphire, yellow = gold), or a dead end.

118493.description:
Frog and Toad is a curious race game for 3-6 players. The players control froads (or is that togs?), creatures which are never quite sure whether they are hopping frogs or walking toads. The froads need to escape from their current environment which they do by racing down two spiraling roads to the exits, collecting bonus tokens on the way.

In each round of the game players first select the actions their froads will take from a shopping list of available actions. Then they move their froads. Depending on the situation, players will find that some actions are better than others, but each action may only be selected once in a round, so players scramble to select what they think will be their best actions, whilst second guessing what the other players will do.

Some actions that players may select change the settings of the game – who selects first and moves first, and what the criterion is for earning bonus move tokens. Other actions move your froads with hops or walks, forwards or backwards (going backwards allows you to pick up bonus move tokens). There are even actions that cause both of your froads to move.

There are effectively two separate races, and the winner of the game is the first player to get both of his froads to the end of their roads.
118493.name: Frog and Toad

118494.name: Tic-Tac Two
118494.description: This wooden board game expands on Tic-Tac-Toe. The goal is the same as the original game, to get three pieces in a row, although the game is played on a board with 25 spaces instead of the original nine. On your turn, you can either place a piece, move a piece or pick up the grid with the original nine squares (the standard Tic-Tac-Toe board) and move it to a new location.

118495.name: Escriba
118495.description:
Escriba is an adventure game based on Bible stories. The game is set in the Old Testament times. One player is the Master and will coordinate the adventure. The other players are pilgrims on the land, facing several adversities.

The Master will lead the pilgrims through one of 20 adventures contained in the Adventure Book. As the game goes on, the pilgrims will collect points from the results of the battles against the adversities and from a list of Bible questions they have to answer. The player with the most points in the end of the adventure wins the game.

118496.name: Trivial Pursuit: Disney for All
118496.description:
From the publisher:

Which Disney character would you most trust with a secret? What are the superpowers of the INCREDIBLES family? Whatever your screen favorites, you’ll find something you love in this version of TRIVIAL PURSUIT. You’ll uncover tons of fun facts - and enjoy three different ways to earn wedges. Choose from Disney List questions, Take 2 Trivia or even My Disney, where you find out how well your teammates know you!

This game even puts DISNEY magic right into your hands with a specially designed Magic Wand that reveals the answers!

Comes with 1 Gameboard, 1 Die, 2 Movers, 12 Wedges, 297 Cards, 1 Magic Wand and Instructions.

118497.description:
Trick of the Rails, themed on the rise of the American railway period, combines 18XX-like portfolio management and a trick-taking card game. Players collect stock certificates and make the companies more valuable by laying the rail network.

The game alternates between stock rounds and operating rounds. In stock rounds, the cards played become shares for the players. In operating rounds, the cards played become track for the companies. The companies get trains, which determine how many track cards they can count for their profit (the trains have costs as well, which may lead to companies not making any profit at all) and in the end, players simply count the value of their shares and highest value wins.
118497.name: Trick of the Rails
boardgamepodcastepisode: Cult of the New Board Game Podcast Episode 029 – Why Jam Improves Your Game
Garrett's Games 335 - Essen Reflections, Keltis & Ingenious Dice, and Trick of the Rails
The Good The Board and The Seriously, I’m running out of material here: Episode 91 “Reimplementations”
Vox Republica 119: The Evolution Of A Pandemic

118498.description:
In the simple but tricky set-collecting card game 9Tours, players plan a sightseeing trip through Thailand, but the trip conductor imposes certain restrictions on what players can do during the nine-day trip. In game terms, players all have a hand of differently colored cards numbered 1–4. Taking turns, they form lines of these cards, but they can neither place the same color twice in a row nor have the cards in a row sum to more than nine. Each time a player plays a card, he takes one of the face-up cards as replacement to his hand.

Making a row sum to nine gains you that row, and you skip your turn for the remainder of the round. Play continues until everyone has a row. The game lasts two rounds, then a final, secret round with the cards left in hand, after which players calculate their score; having the most of one color gains you a bonus, and some special cards factor into your score, too.
118498.name: 9Tours

118499.name: Puss In Boots
118499.description:
The game consists of 31 cards. There are 15 "duets" of 2 cards each and a lucky puss in boots cards. Each side of the duet has pictures and words that go with the other half, and each duet is numbered.

All cards are dealt out. On your turn, you pull a card from the hand of the player on your left. After this, if you have a completed duet of 2 cards, you can lay down one duet per turn. Play continues counterclockwise.

The game ends when all duets are played and the winner is the person who holds the lucky puss in boots card. The winner gathers the duets in numerical order, then reads the fairytale segments on the duets as they receive them.

118500.name: Gildenbrief (Issue 31 - Jul 1994)
rpgpublisher: Verlag für Fantasy- und Science Fiction-Spiele
118500.description: This issue contains an article of the weather in Midgard, and articles about the pilgrims. It also contains an article of new rule ideas.
